dorms.name: 1838 Chicago
dorms.blurb: Formerly home to the Public Affairs Residential College, 1838 Chicago will open as a freshman-only residence during the 2016-17 school year. The building is a stone's throw from the Arch, and the Intercampus shuttle sits right outside the dorm's front door. In addition to new community spaces on the first floor, the renovated facility will include a recreation and performance room to provide students with a workout spot that's closer than Henry Crown Sports Pavillion or Blom. 1838 Chicago will also have suite options.

dorms.name: Allison Residential Community
dorms.blurb: Allison Hall is a residential community located on the south side of campus, with easy access to downtown Evanston. It houses approximately 350 students over four floors and has a live-in professor. On campus, many people refer to Allison as “Hotel Allison” due to recent renovations that gave Allison residents spacious rooms and lounges as well as well-kept bathrooms.

dorms.name: Ayers College of Commerce and Industry
dorms.blurb: Ayers Residential College, otherwise known as the College of Commerce and Industry (CCI), is a business and economics-themed residential college on North Campus. Mostly freshman and sophomores live in this mid-sized res college, and partake in group activities such as intramural sports and the annual business symposium. Located in a prime spot next to North Beach, Lisa’s Cafe and one of the main gyms, Henry Crown Sports Pavilion, CCI is a hidden gem.

dorms.name: Bobb-McCulloch Hall
dorms.blurb: Once dubbed the biggest party dorm in America, Bobb-McCulloch is one of Northwestern students’ favorite residence halls. Often competitive with the all freshmen Elder Residential Community, Bobb residents contend that it is far superior, due to its closer proximity to dining halls, fun atmosphere and a notable presence of upperclassmen. With a prime location inside the fraternity quad, Bobb residents have easy access to a fun nightlife – at least a few nights a week. Residents, however, often use the study lounges to do homework in groups and hang out together. Its only downfalls are the smell, its dirtiness and subpar facilities.

dorms.name: Chapin Hall
dorms.blurb: Chapin Hall is the Humanities Residential College, open to all majors. With its spacious lounges and rooms, clean bathrooms, grand staircase and old-fashioned decor, to call Chapin the fanciest dorm of Northwestern would not be an exaggeration. It houses about 70 students, mostly freshmen and sophomores. Its location on the southwest corner of campus permits easy access to downtown Evanston.

dorms.name: College of Cultural and Community Studies
dorms.short_name: College of Cultural and Community Studies
dorms.blurb: As the smallest and oldest residential college on campus, the College of Cultural and Community Studies (CCS) boasts eclectic, vaguely Ikea-inspired interior design, close-knit community and collective interest in cultural exploration, on campus and beyond. Although located on North Campus, CCS is home to students of diverse majors and backgrounds. Regular firesides and excursions into cultural neighborhoods like Pilsen and Argyle connect residents to faculty fellows, while quirky traditions like Secret Satan – where residents steal each others’ clothes before Halloween – and Service Auction – where residents sell their goods, services, companionship and more for charity – bring together residents for inter-RC fun and festivities.

dorms.name: East Fairchild (Communications Residential College)
dorms.blurb: Located in the heart of South Campus academic buildings, East Fairchild, also known as the Communications Residential College, is a smaller dorm home to budding screenwriters, vigilant journalists and dedicated engineers alike. With four lounges on every floor, each of which finally received some much-needed new furniture last summer, residents are hard-pressed to choose where to do their homework or talk with friends. For a break from the schoolwork grind, students flock to one of the two screening rooms, the in-house exercise room or the main lounge to forge lasting friendships with other residents. Many students say they feel instantly immersed in a tight-knit community by participating in secret traditions from day one.

dorms.name: Elder Residential Community
dorms.blurb: Along with 1838 Chicago, Elder is one of two all-freshman dorm on campus and is known for its extremely social atmosphere. Since it’s a very large dorm, there’s always something fun going on. With weekly get-togethers for cider and donuts and frequent “Elder Munchies,” there are many opportunities to bond with fellow residents. The dining hall and numerous study rooms are notable amenities.

dorms.name: Goodrich House Residential Hall
dorms.blurb: Goodrich House Residence Hall, one of Northwestern's smallest housing facilities, will reopen this school year in the Fraternity Quad. Improvements include a new lounge, kitchen, pantry, laundry and community areas, in addition to suite-style living spaces. Goodrich is perfect for any student looking for a little peace and quiet, with almost all single rooms. Located on North Campus, Goodrich might be the perfect balance for a student looking to be close to the action in the Fraternity Quad, while still having their own private space that's quieter than Bobb or Elder.

dorms.name: GREEN House
dorms.blurb: GREEN House is a residence located on North Campus in the fraternity quad that houses about 50 students. The building’s name is actually an acronym for Group Residence for Environmental Engagement at Northwestern, and it was built to promote environmental sustainability and awareness. Its residents come from a variety of majors and interests. They participate in campus activities on green living – and always crush the campus conservation contest Green Cup. GREEN House’s lounges provide a space for residents to hang out during their free time. They also share a building with the College of Cultural and Community Sciences.

dorms.name: Hobart House (Womens Residential College)
dorms.blurb: Hobart House, also known as Women’s Residential College, is the only all-female dorm at Northwestern. Located at the center of the sorority quad on South Campus, Hobart has the best location to get access to downtown Evanston, University Library and three dining halls (Plex, Allison and Hinman). Hobart houses 50 undergraduate women of various majors and backgrounds, making it a close and inclusive community.

dorms.name: Jones Fine and Performing Arts Residential College
dorms.blurb: If you have a passion for the arts – be it performance, design or even just a general appreciation – Jones Residential College is the place for you. A community of diverse, creative individuals, Jones is known for its welcoming atmosphere.  Popular traditions include performance hour, weekly munchies and SUMO, a notorious secret known only to residents. With eight practice rooms, studios for art, music and dance production, a dark room, study den and a brand new exercise room, Jones has something for everyone. Yet the crown jewel of Jones is the Great Room – a dedicated performance space for residents and student groups. All performances in this space are free for Jones residents. Located on the southernmost tip of campus, Jones is home to mostly freshman and sophomore students and is conveniently located near many Weinberg, Medill and School of Communication buildings.

dorms.name: Jones Fine and Performing Arts Residential College
dorms.blurb: If you have a passion for the arts – be it performance, design or even just a general appreciation – Jones Residential College is the place for you. A community of diverse, creative individuals, Jones is known for its welcoming atmosphere.  Popular traditions include performance hour, weekly munchies and SUMO, a notorious secret known only to residents. With eight practice rooms, studios for art, music and dance production, a dark room, study den and a brand new exercise room, Jones has something for everyone. Yet the crown jewel of Jones is the Great Room – a dedicated performance space for residents and student groups. All performances in this space are free for Jones residents. Located on the southernmost tip of campus, Jones is home to mostly freshman and sophomore students and is conveniently located near many Weinberg, Medill and School of Communication buildings.

dorms.name: Public Affairs Residential College at North Mid-Quads
dorms.blurb: With brand new facilities as of fall 2015, the Public Affairs Residential College has earned a reputation as one of the nicest buildings on campus. A spacious kitchen is well-suited for cooking, and the bathrooms are rumored to be legendary. As a residential college, PARC also hosts thematic programming and integrates interaction with faculty fellows. Residents of PARC typically eat meals in the Allison Residential Community dining hall, but its convenient location makes it easy to branch out, whether it’s on Northwestern’s campus or in downtown Evanston.

dorms.name: Rogers House Residence Hall
dorms.blurb: Rogers House is a small residential hall on South Campus, known for its spacious rooms and calm atmosphere. Although located in the sorority quad, many students feel that the low number of residents can make the dorm a little anti-social. Additionally, in Rogers House, women and men live on separate floors, which is different from most other residential houses at Northwestern. The dorm is also located close to downtown Evanston and about equally far from various dining options, such as Allison and Plex.

dorms.name: Sargent Hall
dorms.blurb: Perhaps best known for its dining hall, Sargent Hall on North Campus houses mostly freshman and sophomores. Sargent living makes it easy to roll right out of bed and head to Tech for a 9 a.m. or make it to the fraternity quad in under a minute. It's also conveniently located a minute-walk away from Henry Crown Sports Pavilion, the main campus gym. Although it is the best go-to for food on North Campus, there is still ongoing debate between whether Sargent or Allison has better dining.

dorms.name: Slivka Residential College
dorms.blurb: Home to the Residential College of Science and Engineering, Slivka’s tight-knit community is a haven for the scientifically inclined. But regardless of major, Slivka is an ideal option for anyone hoping to live up north in clean, comfortable and spacious accomodations. Residents live in suites made up of doubles and singles and hang out together in their communal recreation room, floor kitchens, music practice room and study lounges. With Lisa’s Cafe right downstairs, Slivka residents never go hungry.

dorms.name: Shepard Residential College at South Mid Quads
dorms.blurb: Similar to PARC, Shepard Residential College reopened after extensive renovations during the 2014-2015 school year. A non-thematic residential college, Shepard attracts a diverse range of students who engage with faculty fellows. Shepard is also known for its longstanding rivalry with Willard Residential College, played out each year in the annual Woo-Shep Olympics. Shepard has a designated dining room in Allison and is located near downtown Evanston.

dorms.name: Shepard Hall
dorms.blurb: The building formerly home to Shepard Residential College will reopen this year as Shepard Hall. The residential college, which confusingly shares the name Shepard, permanently relocated to the South Mid-Quads. In addition to new bathroom facilities (always a plus), the building will feature flexible community spaces including performance spaces, study rooms, a kitchen area, classroom and lecture seating, computer rooms and a meditation room. The building will also feature suite-style living areas.

dorms.name: West Fairchild (International Studies Residential College)
dorms.blurb: This South Campus residential college goes by many names: ISRC, International Studies Residential College, West Fairchild, Best Fairchild (if you ask a spirited ISRC resident), Worst Fairchild (if you ask a resident of its rival dorm, CRC/East Fairchild) and “What’s that?” (if you ask anyone who lives on North Campus, and probably a large percentage of South Campus residents too). Its naysayers say ISRC is a decrepit building with absurdly tiny rooms and an anti-social atmosphere, but many of its residents love the sense of community, suite/lounge setup and abundant free food. It may not be the dorm for hardcore partiers or aspiring frat stars, but if you’re looking for a small, quiet South Campus dorm with a gigantic pineapple mascot, it may be the place for you. Plus, renovations over the past summer mean better furniture, new wood-laminate floors and improved bedroom furniture to make life a little more bearable.

dorms.name: Willard Residential College at 1835 Hinman
dorms.blurb: Located on South Campus near downtown Evanston, Willard's original location in the sorority quad is under renovation during the 2016-17 school year. With that, the residential college community affectionately known as "Wooshack" will be moved to the 1835 Hinman building while repairs are made to the old building. The community, once home to Stephen Colbert and Julia Louis-Dreyfus, will pick up in its new home, including Fran's Cafe, which will serve as the late-night dining location for South Campus residents this year. Hinman’s five stories give an almost clear view of Lake Michigan.  The two lounges on the first floor equipped with a TV, billiards table, piano and a multitude of seating areas heighten Hinman’s cozy feel. Hinman’s suite-style living arrangements add to its homey atmosphere with a lounge and bathroom per six rooms and two kitchens per floor.

images.name: 1838chicago1
images.undefined: leave these with the underscore please

quotes.name: allison1
quotes.text: Allison is a quiet community that was a big change from living in Elder last year. The amenities are great, especially with the laundry machines on each floor, but the nonexistent community isn't something to be overlooked.

quotes.name: allison2
quotes.text: It’s exactly like a hotel; great facilities, but don’t expect to become best friends with the people next door.

quotes.name: allison3
quotes.text: Allison is a beautiful building and a great place to find amazing friends.

quotes.name: allison4
quotes.text: Allison has nice amenities, good location relative to Evanston and basically no social interaction. It is the end of Spring Quarter, and I still don't know the name of my next-door neighbors, and I'm a pretty friendly person.

quotes.name: allison5
quotes.text: Allison Hall is a great place to live if you want a quiet living environment.

quotes.name: allison6
quotes.text: Allison has amazing facilities – the rooms are big, the furniture is nice, the bathrooms are really nice. If you’re proactive about meeting people on your floor, then you’ll be able to make friends, but Allison is definitely not as sociable as Elder or Bobb.

quotes.name: ayers1
quotes.text: I like all the activities they have available to the people who live here. I really like the location because it’s close to [Henry Crown Sports Pavillion]. The thing I don’t like is that the closest dining hall is Sargent, which is still kind of far.
quotes.dorm: Ayers College of Commerce and Industry

quotes.name: ayers2
quotes.text: The community is really nice. Everyone’s pretty close to each other. If you want to make friends, it’s a good place to live. The facilities are nice, and if you want to do work, it’s always quiet if you need to, but if you want to hang out, then you can always do that too. It’s like best of both worlds. It can be loud at times, but you can just go somewhere else.
quotes.dorm: Ayers College of Commerce and Industry

quotes.name: ayers3
quotes.text: The community is fantastic. The people here are just so nice and welcoming. I’m a sophomore, and I stayed here after my freshman year because I liked it so much.
quotes.dorm: Ayers College of Commerce and Industry

quotes.name: ayers4
quotes.text: The lounge is a great place to work. It’s comfortable. I’ve met some great friends… Maybe there could be a way to have more personal interactions between residents. It’s just after a while, people stick to their own groups, and it would be nice to have people from different groups have some more personal connections.
quotes.dorm: Ayers College of Commerce and Industry

quotes.name: ccs1
quotes.text: Living in CCS has been an amazing experience, and I would not have changed any part of it. CCS is a great place where you can explore who you are as well as who you are becoming. It is a warm and welcoming community that is immensely supportive of people as they transition into college life. Most of my favorite memories of freshman year either took place in my res college or involved the people who live there with me. Whether attending football games, LGBTQA inclusion talks or family dinners in the CCS room, I can always count on my fellow CCSers to be by my side.
quotes.dorm: College of Cultural and Community Studies

quotes.name: ccs2
quotes.text: CCS has a really nice and close-knit community because it has so few residents. You will definitely get to know the people you live with if you attend events and spend time in the lounge. There are lots of opportunities to socialize, but it's also pretty quiet and there's usually nothing too crazy going on, so you always have a nice, relaxed place to come back to at the end of the day.
quotes.source: Lauren Ché Anderson Justice, Weinberg freshman
quotes.dorm: College of Cultural and Community Studies

quotes.name: ccs3
quotes.text: I love living in CCS because we're more like a family than just a dorm. Even though we are the smallest res college, we have a wide range of people from different backgrounds and with varying interests. And you're sure to find someone that matches yours, whether you wanna go out at night or stay in and play board games! Our facilities, bathrooms, rooms and lounges are wonderful and everything certainly has a chic, but homey feel!
quotes.dorm: College of Cultural and Community Studies

quotes.name: ccs4
quotes.text:
We have tons of washers and dryers compared to the number of students living here, especially compared to the bigger dorms like Bobb or Elder. Since it’s such a small dorm, you get a lot of personal amenities.
 The community is really good. Everyone is really supportive. People hang out in the lounge.  We hang out on weekends or weeknights.  People like to do IMs.  It’s not the only thing people do with their time, but for most of the people who live there, it’s a large part of their time. They enjoy engaging with other people in the community.
quotes.dorm: College of Cultural and Community Studies

quotes.name: ccs5
quotes.text: We’re really small, so both last year and this year, we got the opportunity to really get to know everyone on at least some basic level, which I feel like most of the other dorms don’t get to do. We have a very chill and welcoming vibe to the whole building.
quotes.dorm: College of Cultural and Community Studies

quotes.name: ccs6
quotes.text:
It’s a very small tight-knit community, and it’s really well-located.  It’s close to Tech, it’s close to the gym, it’s close to food.
 It’s really far away from downtown Evanston. Most of the restaurants are on the end of the campus, so if I want to do some shopping...it’s kind of displaced from the city of Evanston.
quotes.dorm: College of Cultural and Community Studies

quotes.name: elder1
quotes.text: So my favorite part about Elder is it’s very social, everyone here is a freshman, everyone gets to know each other, there’s no like, hostility between anyone. The lounges are really nice ‘cause it brings people together, everyone just goes out and hangs out there. On the negative side… I don’t really have anything negative to say, I like Elder, it’s a nice facility too.

quotes.name: elder2
quotes.text: Our lounge is like very tight so we have a lot of friends that like come out here and just hang out and like help with homework or play games, it’s just awesome like that.

quotes.name: elder3
quotes.text: Elder is a good community where people aren’t scared to meet each other compared to other dorms. The lounge is a place where I’ve met a lot of people that I didn’t think I’d become friends with just by walking into the lounge and meeting them there.

quotes.name: elder4
quotes.text: It’s great because everyone’s a freshman, we’re all taking relatively the same classes, so if we ever need help, we just go to the lounge and hang out. And the vibe encourages us to hang out and know each other more, so everyone on my floor at least is really good friends.

quotes.name: willard1
quotes.text: I've decided to live in Hinman twice in my time at Northwestern because of the people. While the facilities aren't the nicest, I think Hinman creates an awesome community. The lounges every few rooms connects people much better than a building with only one or two lounges, or potentially even none. Having a dining hall and C-Store is great during the freezing winter, and it's close to downtown and many South Campus buildings. Overall, Hinman was one of the best decisions I made.

quotes.name: willard2
quotes.text: The best thing about it is the lake view. It’s also got a nice dining hall, which is a good option especially in the winter, when you might not want to leave your dorm. There’s a fire alarm that goes off every now and then, so at least you know that it’s safe.

quotes.name: willard3
quotes.text: Hinman’s not the nicest dorm in terms of amenities. The kitchenettes aren’t that usable, the rooms are smaller than others – it’s got a dining hall though, so that’s pretty great. If you’re a Bienen or Medill student, it’s amazing, since you can see your classes from your room. It’s that close. The lounges are really nice, since they’re a great place to do homework, or play games with friends.
quotes.source: Nate Pham, Weinberg and Bienen sophomore

quotes.name: willard4
quotes.text: I have a roof over my head and a dining hall in the same building – I mean, that’s all I can really ask for.

quotes.name: smq1
quotes.text: While SMQ doesn’t boast the largest rooms or largest dorm on campus, it more than makes up for it with its inclusive and tight-knit community. There are always students in the lobby whether they’re playing Smash, competing in ping-pong, or watching the NBA playoffs. The atmosphere and community of a dorm is its most defining characteristic; in that regard, there are few competitors to SMQ.
quotes.dorm: Shepard Residential College at South Mid Quads

quotes.name: smq2
quotes.text: With its new lovely renovations, SMQ has become the eye candy of the south campus dorms. Sporting a sleek modern design for the entire building, along with its fully equipped kitchen, other dorms pale in comparison to its beauty. However, its true allure is with the daily shenanigans that goes on in the building.
quotes.dorm: Shepard Residential College at South Mid Quads

quotes.name: smq3
quotes.text: I live there now and I’ll be back for next year, so clearly I’m biased, but really I think it’s been a great community for me. Many of my best friends I met here, and I’m now on the exec board as social chair. We’re kind of a crazy community, a lot of us are really good friends, and there’s always people hanging in the lounge, playing ping pong or video games or studying.
quotes.dorm: Shepard Residential College at South Mid Quads

quotes.name: smq4
quotes.text: Thanks to its relative small size with around 60 residents, SMQ has a small and tight-knit community that is almost “cult-like.” The community is quirky yet diverse, so everyone can easily find other people with similar interests. On top of that, we boast the best facilities on campus, including a full-equipped kitchen, a new electronic piano and hotel-level bathrooms.
quotes.dorm: Shepard Residential College at South Mid Quads

quotes.name: slivka1
quotes.text: There’s always something going on. Even if you’re bored, there’s always something to do. People are just really nice and it’s always easy to find friends.

quotes.name: slivka2
quotes.text: What’s special is the community. There is always something going on in the background, whether it’s actual social events like watching movies or just hanging out. I like that it’s really close.
quotes.source: Luis De La Garza, McCormick sophomore

quotes.name: slivka3
quotes.text: Something completely unique about Slivka is the mixture of people who are interested in science and mathematics and engineering, and also sports and videogames.

quotes.name: slivka4
quotes.text: Slivka is a good place to live, mostly because we are a tight-knit community. We have fun events that we do together. We have professors that come in once or twice a week. It’s a place where you can also branch out. We have our token Medill kid, our acting kid. It’s also about meeting other people and expanding your interests rather than being stuck in one central mode.

quotes.name: slivka5
quotes.text: When I visited as a senior in high school, I stayed overnight and my host lived in Slivka, and so I just kind of had firsthand exposure to it, and it seemed really nice. I liked the suite-style of living, and it was on North Campus. I’m up here a lot, because most of my classes are in Tech. I just got a really good sense of the community here, which is also part of the reason why I wanted to live here.

quotes.name: Sargent1
quotes.text: I’m an engineer and we’re really close to Tech, so I can just roll out of bed five minutes before class and make it there through the little basement tunnel. We only have a lounge and a kitchen on one floor, and I know one flight of stairs is not a lot but it’s just irritating.

quotes.name: Sargent2
quotes.text: I love the people, and I say I don’t like living on North Campus because it’s far from South Campus, but it’s literally four blocks. I love living in Sargent and I love that it’s close to [Henry Crown Sports Pavillion].

quotes.name: Sargent3
quotes.text: I love the overhead storage. That is [one hundred percent] my favorite.

quotes.name: parc1
quotes.text: I enjoy the firm sense of community that exists at PARC and the diversity of its constituents. It’s far from North Campus, so getting there is quite a walk.
quotes.dorm: Public Affairs Residential College at North Mid-Quads

quotes.name: parc2
quotes.text: PARC is great because of all the programing that goes on, and it has really nice facilities. It’s really close to Evanston which is convenient. It’s a little far from central campus, but I think the niceness makes up for it.
quotes.dorm: Public Affairs Residential College at North Mid-Quads

quotes.name: parc3
quotes.text:
I like that it’s close to Evanston. Even though being an engineer and having to walk up north every time,
the building is nice enough to make it worth the walk.
quotes.dorm: Public Affairs Residential College at North Mid-Quads

quotes.name: parc4
quotes.text: What I really like about PARC is that the common space on the first floor is really conducive to community building. Whether it’s baking together in the kitchen, or crowding together by the TV to watch Game of Thrones, it’s just a really open space.
quotes.dorm: Public Affairs Residential College at North Mid-Quads

quotes.name: parc5
quotes.text: PARC helped me to feel more at home at school and like I had a stable group of friends. Schooldude responses have been particularly super slow for this building, however.
quotes.dorm: Public Affairs Residential College at North Mid-Quads

quotes.name: jones1
quotes.text: It’s super convenient location-wise. It’s right on the lake, so if you get a room that faces east you have a view of the lake. It’s right next to a dining hall, so you do technically have to go outside, but not very far.
quotes.dorm: Jones Fine and Performing Arts Residential College

quotes.name: jones2
quotes.text: It’s a very friendly place. People don’t sing, dance and yell all the time. So it’s not like a thing people should worry when coming in, like, ‘Is it just going to be theater people screaming?’ No, there’s actually people here besides theater and even the theater people themselves have other interests.
quotes.dorm: Jones Fine and Performing Arts Residential College

quotes.name: jones3
quotes.text: I definitely use the practice rooms a couple times a week at least. The acoustics in the practice rooms themselves aren't the greatest, just because they weren't designed to be practice rooms, but it’s really convenient having practice rooms in here.
quotes.dorm: Jones Fine and Performing Arts Residential College

quotes.name: jones4
quotes.text: I really like the suite-style system. It's definitely more social than hall-style because we have these lounges all over the building and you get to know people in your suite really well and even the people in the next suite over.
quotes.dorm: Jones Fine and Performing Arts Residential College

quotes.name: jones5
quotes.text: It’s quaint I guess. It’s kind of dinky. Also stuff is always breaking, like the elevator, or kitchen appliances or the fire alarm [will go off].
quotes.dorm: Jones Fine and Performing Arts Residential College

quotes.name: isrc1
quotes.text: The community isn’t bad. I’m not really involved in it, but it’s there. It’s a good dorm for freshmen, especially if you’re looking for a smaller community, but I wouldn’t live here again.

quotes.name: isrc2
quotes.text: I like that it’s small. I think the community is really nice, you really get to know people. It’s a pretty social dorm, especially since we have the suites. The rooms are nice, and I like that there’s wood floors instead of carpet.

quotes.name: isrc3
quotes.text: The location is a plus. It's really close to downtown Evanston, the library, and a couple dining halls. However, the facilities are not the best. The community isn't closely-knit, but you definitely can make friends if you want to.

quotes.name: hobart1
quotes.text: It’s one of the hidden gems on campus. It’s really clean...we have some of the best facilities of any dorm on campus. We have a gym, a computer lounge, two TV lounges...Anytime anyone walks in here that’s never been here will be like ‘wow, this is the most beautiful place on campus’.

quotes.name: hobart2
quotes.text: The reason why I chose to live here and really love it is the community. Because we are a residential college, we focus a lot on actually getting to know the people living in Hobart and doing events with them.

quotes.name: hobart3
quotes.text: We have a lot of movie nights, and we also do games...we often have nights when everyone’s just hanging around and play games.

quotes.name: hobart4
quotes.text: Hobart House is very clean and organized. All the facilities are in great conditions because they are relatively new. Though I enjoy being here not just because of the environment, but for the people as well. Everyone here is like family to me even though we are from very different places.

quotes.name: green1
quotes.text: GREEN House isn’t actually green as most people think.

quotes.name: green2
quotes.text: To find a tighter knit community, you’d need some yarn. Great place to live and relax.

quotes.name: green3
quotes.text: GREEN House is a hidden gem on North Campus.

quotes.name: green4
quotes.text: The dorm was really nice, and I enjoyed the company of the people on my floor.

quotes.name: chapin1
quotes.text: Living in Chapin doesn’t suck. The rooms are really big. Several great experiences I’ve had in Chapin include being late at night, feeling very tired, but instead of going to bed, I play Settlers of Catan, watch movies or just talk about life with Chapinos.

quotes.name: chapin2
quotes.text: I remember the first week that I was here, during Wildcat Welcome, a lot of the upperclassmen had already moved in because they were helping with Purple Posse, and I meant this guy named Noah, and Noah is my best friend now. I didn’t know at the time I would grow to be very fond of the community, but I did. I remember late at night we were playing pool or something, and talking about what it means to be a Northwestern student. That helped me out a lot.

quotes.name: chapin3
quotes.text: It's a chill place to live. People here are really nice, very relaxing, dorms are really big and that was a real big fuss. I think it's the biggest on campus, actually.

quotes.name: chapin4
quotes.text: I would say we are quirky, we are Chamily and we are kind of eclectic. We have people of all different schools and majors, with different interests and things they like to do, but somehow it all sort of works.

quotes.name: crc1
quotes.text: There is always something going on at CRC, making it incredibly easy to get involved but also low pressure to attend every single event. CRC mirrors the NU social scene unlike any other dorm.

quotes.name: crc2
quotes.text: I think CRC compared to a lot of other residential halls and residential colleges has smaller facilities and some might see it as worn down, we did get renovated this past year, so we have nice carpeting, loftable beds, which is nice. I think the community and the size, it’s about 100 to 110 people plus non-residents members really allows a lot of people to people to get to know each other, along with the suites, which are really cool places to hang out.

quotes.name: crc3
quotes.text: Living in CRC is a blast! Everyone's super fun and super weird. There's a real sense of community here that's mostly because of the awesome, crazy people.

quotes.name: crc4
quotes.text: CRC was a great community to come into freshman year because everyone was so welcoming and friendly. The screening rooms we have are great for bonding with other CRCers over favorite movies, and CRC has the best location on campus, especially for School of Comm, Medill and Bienen students.

quotes.name: crc5
quotes.text: CRC is definitely a community that welcomed me to Northwestern and made me feel at home during my transition to college freshman year. I've made so many friends and memories living here, and the facilities are completely unparalleled. It also helps that it has about a 60-40 freshmen to upperclassmen ratio. Because of that, many of my friends are sophomores who have given me sage advice throughout the year.

quotes.name: rogers1
quotes.text: I like that's it's a smaller dorm so you know everyone, and it feels more like a home. I like that the rooms are really big and it's usually quiet, so you can get enough sleep but also can go out when you want. I like that it's South Campus so I'm closer to downtown Evanston. It's not as social as I wish it was, but it's easy to make a good group of friends in the dorm and then it's fun. I also like that it’s in the sorority quad, because it’s beautiful. Also important to note: There’s only two washing machines, and they’re almost always full.

quotes.name: rogers2
quotes.text: I’ve loved living in RoHo for many reasons. It is very quiet and homey, so I can go out every day and do whatever I want and know I get to come home to some peace and quiet. People say it is unsocial, but I would disagree. As an extrovert, those of us who want to make an effort to be social have become very close friends. We also have awesome munchies, activities or free things to do outside of the house quite often. The room sizes are amazing and the bathrooms are very clean. The only downside I would really mention is the lack of washing machines and dryers… two of each is definitely not enough. However, we have a great lounge area with a television and tables and a ping-pong table. The location [of the dorm] in the middle of the sorority quad is great for being in a sorority or having classes down south, but not conducive to partying north all the time. It’s also really annoying to have to tell people what Rogers is because no one knows.

quotes.name: rogers3
quotes.text: I'd say that I like RoHo because the facilities are very nice and the rooms are very big and it feels homey because it is so small.  I love every part about it as a sophomore, but I lived here last year as a freshman and the one downside was that I did not immediately make as many friends simply because the dorm is so small.
quotes.source: Chris Landy, Bienen and Communication sophomore

quotes.name: rogers4
quotes.text: Rogers House is a chill but still very social environment. It's honestly a hidden gem at Northwestern. As a freshman, it probably isn't as big or as social as most people would want. But it is still an amazing environment and the people are great. Also the rooms are probably the biggest on campus with amazing amenities. I have nothing but good things to say about RoHo.

quotes.name: bobb1
quotes.text: This dorm is honestly just disgusting and past its prime.

quotes.name: bobb2
quotes.text: Bobb has honestly been a great place to live freshman year. It's kind of gross but not nearly as gross as people make it out to be, and everyone is really nice and friendly and fun.
quotes.source: Eliana Galperin, School of Communciation freshman

quotes.name: bobb3
quotes.text: It is what you make it to be. It's great that everyone is very friendly and social. However, the amenities aren't great and you have to turn a blind eye to them.

quotes.name: bobb4
quotes.text: Bobb is a great place, maybe not the cleanest, but it’s where I met my best friends and I loved living here my freshman year.

nonres_quotes.name: allison1
nonres_quotes.text: Allison is known to be one of the nicest dorms on campus, leading to the name Hotel Allison. The rooms are pretty big with a standard set-up, so you can decorate it and easily make it your own. I love going to Allison when I'm on South Campus to see my friends, but I do not think it is one of the most social places.

nonres_quotes.name: allison2
nonres_quotes.text: Allison is the best dorm to live in if you want to live south. It has great common rooms. I was shocked when comparing it to other dorms I've been in. It has a great reputation, especially for meeting people.

nonres_quotes.name: allison3
nonres_quotes.text: From what I've seen it’s super super nice although the dining hall is a bit overrated. I've heard it's a good community but it's quieter than up north.

nonres_quotes.name: allison4
nonres_quotes.text: Allison is a good dorm to live in on South Campus if you care a lot about how big your room is. There are a lot of people on each floor, and there is mixing between freshman and sophomores, but it's really anti-social compared to any of the major North Campus dorms. Even compared to Willard, it's antisocial. Before you get to campus, people emphasize how amazing Allison is because of how nice the facilities are, but that's really overrated. You're a freshman once, and Allison isn't really the dorm to live in if you want to make friends in your dorm.

nonres_quotes.name: ayers1
nonres_quotes.text: I have friends who live in Ayers who are super nice, and I’ve heard they have a great community. I’ve heard the dorm itself is a really nice place to live too.
nonres_quotes.dorm: Ayers College of Commerce and Industry

nonres_quotes.name: ayers2
nonres_quotes.text: I've noticed many of my friends who are science-oriented want to live in either Kemper or Ayers given the convenience and quality of the dorms.
nonres_quotes.dorm: Ayers College of Commerce and Industry

nonres_quotes.name: ayers3
nonres_quotes.text: My friends who live in Ayers like it. Everyone I know who lived there last year all liked it and lived there again, except one who became an RA.
nonres_quotes.dorm: Ayers College of Commerce and Industry

nonres_quotes.name: elder1
nonres_quotes.text: I’m jealous of Elder’s elevators as well as the fact that they have nicer lounges and all the residents are freshman so they seemed to be better friends. Even though the food in the dining hall isn’t that great it is still nice that they have it there as an option.

nonres_quotes.name: elder2
nonres_quotes.text: I have so many friends in Elder and constantly find myself at the study room and dining hall. It’s a lot easier to get work done in Elder than in Bobb because it’s more quiet and the study rooms are nicer.

nonres_quotes.name: elder3
nonres_quotes.text: I find myself in Elder almost every time I go out. It is the perfect place to start the night, especially if you’re going to a fraternity because it’s right across the street from the frat quad.

nonres_quotes.name: hinman1
nonres_quotes.text: I like the lounges because the lounges in my dorm [Hobart House] are inconvenient. I don’t even know some of the people who live in my hall. Here I’ll see people passing through and know who they are and where they live.

nonres_quotes.name: hinman2
nonres_quotes.text: It’s not necessarily a top choice dorm, but among the south campus dorms it’s a decent option if you want a large-ish dorm and can’t get in to Allison. One of the main selling points I’d say is that it has an attached dining hall, which is way more convenient than a lot of people realize.

nonres_quotes.name: hinman3
nonres_quotes.text: Hinman is really south and I’ve never eaten there to be honest.

nonres_quotes.name: willard1
nonres_quotes.text: It’s definitely not the worst place you can end up at. It might not be as pretty as the Green House or the other recently renovated buildings, but having the lounges and the kitchenettes on every floor definitely gives it the edge over somewhere like Foster Walker.

nonres_quotes.name: willard2
nonres_quotes.text: Honestly, the lounges are the best part of Hinman. Not many dorms have a lounge on every floor, and even though I don’t visit Hinman often, I think that’s pretty great.

nonres_quotes.name: slivka1
nonres_quotes.text: It’s beautiful. One of the bigger dorms on campus and actually has really strong community. Since it’s all engineers, they work together. It’s automatic people to have in your classes and work with.

nonres_quotes.name: slivka2
nonres_quotes.text: I’ve been over there a couple of times. I have worked in their study rooms, which are amazing. They have these white boards and I remember my freshman year when I spent, like, 16 hours with people doing our first math homework in that room. It was unreasonable. But the facilities are super cool; the rooms are huge and beautiful and well furnished.

nonres_quotes.name: slivka3
nonres_quotes.text: I think living in Slivka would be nice, just because if you ever need anything, you could go down to Lisa’s. And if you’re hungry, you can go down to Lisa’s. So, that’s nice. And, I guess if you’re also an engineer, that also would be nice, because you’re so close to Tech. It’s in front of the frat quad, so that’s nice. And if you need to go to the gym, it’s in front of SPAC.

nonres_quotes.name: Sargent1
nonres_quotes.text: My dad did his undergrad here at Northwestern and he lived in Sargent. He said it hasn’t changed since then.

nonres_quotes.name: Sargent2
nonres_quotes.text: My impressions of it before were like, no matter what, don’t go to Sarge, it’s the worst place to live. But my friend’s room in Sarge is better than my room in Bobb. Maybe it depends on the room. I definitely don’t think it’s as bad as they made it out to be.

nonres_quotes.name: parc1
nonres_quotes.text: They all talk to each other and are actually friends with each other. They greet each other and the common space downstairs is helpful. Sargent doesn’t really have that so not many people talk to each other.
nonres_quotes.dorm: Public Affairs Residential College at North Mid-Quads

nonres_quotes.name: parc2
nonres_quotes.text: It’s a happy, welcoming dorm. The community is always bubbling with personality. Whether it’s late-night study sessions or video game duels, PARC does it well.
nonres_quotes.dorm: Public Affairs Residential College at North Mid-Quads

nonres_quotes.name: parc3
nonres_quotes.text: PARC seems really tight-knit and pretty laid-back. I have a few friends there that really seem to love hanging down in the lobby.
nonres_quotes.dorm: Public Affairs Residential College at North Mid-Quads

nonres_quotes.name: jones1
nonres_quotes.text: I think that if you’re interested in performing or theater or any kind of performance art, then Jones would be a really great place to live. It’s really conveniently located and I’ve heard really positive things about it from everyone who I know who has lived there.
nonres_quotes.dorm: Jones Fine and Performing Arts Residential College

nonres_quotes.name: jones2
nonres_quotes.text: The physical building is similar to many of the residential colleges on campus. it’s divided up into a suite style of living. Since most of the buildings are laid out the same it’s not that difficult to navigate…I do like their performance venue of the Great Room. It’s great for just getting an idea of rehearsing in a bigger space, or performing dance numbers and things like that.
nonres_quotes.dorm: Jones Fine and Performing Arts Residential College

nonres_quotes.name: jones3
nonres_quotes.text: [Jones has] a lot of theater majors so I heard it can get pretty loud there, pretty intense but otherwise I’m sure it’s a fine place. I hear they have a pottery studio, so that sounds pretty cool. I haven’t really been in there that often but it seems like a wild place.
nonres_quotes.dorm: Jones Fine and Performing Arts Residential College

nonres_quotes.name: isrc1
nonres_quotes.text: I haven’t heard much about ISRC, even though I live right next to it. I guess it’s a social dorm, and their mascot is a pineapple, but that’s literally all I know. My dorm, CRC, has Super Smash Bros. tournaments with them, which seems like a cool cross-res college event.

nonres_quotes.name: isrc2
nonres_quotes.text: I hear that's it's very similar to CRC, so it's not exactly a nice dorm but is more known for its community. There are a lot of journalism kids in there.

nonres_quotes.name: isrc3
nonres_quotes.text: I stayed in ISRC during my prospie visit, and it was a pretty nice and laid back dorm. I said I was going to live there, but didn’t. Whoops.

nonres_quotes.name: isrc4
nonres_quotes.text: I stayed in ISRC during BioExcel, a summer program that I did before freshman year. The facilities are old, but the lounges are good for hanging out and studying in, and it’s nice that every floor has a kitchen.

nonres_quotes.name: hobart1
nonres_quotes.text: The sorority quad is really pretty, and there’s a lot of trees and green grass that people can sit on. There's patio furniture, too. It is definitely closer to south campus.

nonres_quotes.name: hobart2
nonres_quotes.text: Hobart is a really nice residential college for girls. It has high quality utilities and close-knit community. Everyone is supportive of each other and everyone strives to create a harmonious residential experience.

nonres_quotes.name: hobart3
nonres_quotes.text: I really enjoy using the gym at Hobart. The gym on the basement is very spacious and clean, so I have enough space for stretching. It also has a big mirror, which makes the room look twice as big. The only drawback is that it doesn't have enough dumbbells of different weights.

nonres_quotes.name: green1
nonres_quotes.text: I don’t exactly know what goes on in GREEN House other than low flow showerheads and energy efficient light bulbs. It was recently renovated and in a great location on campus so it’s probably a nice place to live.

nonres_quotes.name: green2
nonres_quotes.text: I’ve never been to Greenhouse, but I’ve heard it’s good for anyone who wants to live north as a freshman if Bobb, Elder and Sargent fill up before your priority housing time comes along. It’s also helpful for fraternity guys who don’t live in the house as sophomores to live close by.

nonres_quotes.name: green3
nonres_quotes.text: It’s probably one of the better looking dorms. The facilities are really nice.

nonres_quotes.name: green4
nonres_quotes.text: I’ve heard that Greenhouse has very nice, new facilities that are extremely underrated. I have also heard, however, that many people in GREEN House keep to themselves and that it doesn’t really have that community feel that Elder, Bobb and Sargent have.

nonres_quotes.name: green5
nonres_quotes.text: GREEN House seems like the chillest dorm on north campus, except maybe Slivka. While it's in the frat quad, it appears to be more homey and comfortable than other dorms up north. I know a few upperclassmen who have chosen to live in Greenhouse for one or two years after freshman year. The only odd thing is that the bathrooms are co-ed, from what I remember.

nonres_quotes.name: bobb1
nonres_quotes.text: I hear it’s very social.  I feel Bobb and Sargent are a lot more like Comm Studies people. The study lounge is nice to study in. I wouldn’t want to live in Bobb because I feel like it’s kind of dirty and gross. It also seems like a lot of fun, I’ve hung out with people in Bobb before and south campus seems a lot more uptight in terms of what the RA’s let you do. You’re more likely to pregame in Bobb than on south campus.

nonres_quotes.name: bobb2
nonres_quotes.text: I wished I lived in Bobb. It’s convenient. It’s close to Tech, SPAC, and Sargent – the three things I need to go to. Most people in Bobb probably go Greek. It’s loud; if you’re a quiet person it’s probably hard to get your 8 hours. Overall, it’s a great residence hall.

nonres_quotes.name: bobb3
nonres_quotes.text: Bobb is a fun, social dorm with great proximity to important spots on campus like Sargent dining hall, SPAC, and the fraternity quad. It's a close community where students get really close to their floormates. Some of my best friends on campus live in Bobb!

nonres_quotes.name: bobb4
nonres_quotes.text: As a non-resident, Bobb to me is a place to go for social reasons. I always enjoy myself when I am there, and then appreciate the more quiet and clean lifestyle of my own dorm after returning home.

nonres_quotes.name: chapin1
nonres_quotes.text: Chapin is too small.

nonres_quotes.name: chapin2
nonres_quotes.text: The Chapin building looks absolutely gorgeous.  Hands down, Chapin is the most aesthetically pleasing dorm on campus, and the people seem really chill too.

nonres_quotes.name: chapin3
nonres_quotes.text: I know one person who’s ever lived in Chapin, and they’re very low-key.

nonres_quotes.name: crc1
nonres_quotes.text: I think the way CRC is setup creates a great balance between socializing and private time. A sufficient amount of singles are complemented by suites that invite people to be social. The rooms are small though.

nonres_quotes.name: crc2
nonres_quotes.text: I think the location is really great, it’s right in the middle of campus, it’s the closest residential college to norris and most of the south campus buildings.

nonres_quotes.name: crc3
nonres_quotes.text: I have never been to CRC, but I know people that live there and I've heard pretty good things. I haven't heard of anyone who hates it, but I also haven't heard of anyone who is absolutely in love.

nonres_quotes.name: crc4
nonres_quotes.text: I think CRC is one of the smaller, older dorms with not-so-nice facilities, but on the other hand, I feel like it has a really nice community there. A lot of my friends made best friends there... and also I think the layout of the building is pretty good for making friends.

nonres_quotes.name: cci1
nonres_quotes.text: There are students with all different majors. The fact that it’s a business residential college doesn’t affect you. You participate as much as you want to.
nonres_quotes.dorm: Ayers College of Commerce and Industry

nonres_quotes.name: cci2
nonres_quotes.text: The size of the rooms is not emphasized enough. Our rooms are huge and our closet space is really big, even compared to our closets at home. And there is a really great community. I walk down the hall and everyone smiles and says hi. We aren’t a cult like some residential colleges but we like each other.
nonres_quotes.dorm: Ayers College of Commerce and Industry

nonres_quotes.name: cci3
nonres_quotes.text: If you want a quiet atmosphere, you can work in your room, and if you want to see people you can literally just step outside your room and you’ll see people. You can make some great connections and I did. I can always walk into the lounge at 5 a.m. and find people I know because I’ve gotten to know basically everyone.
nonres_quotes.dorm: Ayers College of Commerce and Industry

nonres_quotes.name: cci4
nonres_quotes.text: The best part about CCI is the atmosphere. Last year as a freshman I really liked CCI, but it kind of dies on you during the second year. Facilities wise, it’s pretty loaded. CCI has some of the biggest rooms on campus and all of the lounges are really nice with a big TV and Xbox. We do have ugly painting and fabric schemes though.
nonres_quotes.dorm: Ayers College of Commerce and Industry

nonres_quotes.name: cci5
nonres_quotes.text: I definitely did not picture being here for three years when I came here, but being involved is easy and fun without the commitment. I gained housing points without trying because we had so many events so I got a huge corner room my sophomore year and then a single. It’s a great place to live for three years. I’m kind of sad not to live here next year.
nonres_quotes.dorm: Ayers College of Commerce and Industry

nonres_quotes.name: ccs1
nonres_quotes.text: I think it’s a really good place if you’re interested in having a group of people who want to be really involved in their community and are interested in finding a community within the residential experience. I think CCS is an underrated place to do that.
nonres_quotes.dorm: College of Cultural and Community Studies

nonres_quotes.name: ccs2
nonres_quotes.text: I think CCS is a very tight-knit community.  There are a lot of interesting people.  I can always come to the lounge and I’ll see someone that I know, someone studying, someone playing video games.  They are the epitome of what an RC should be.
nonres_quotes.source: John Franklin, McCormick and Bienen sophomore
nonres_quotes.dorm: College of Cultural and Community Studies

nonres_quotes.name: ccs3
nonres_quotes.text: I think it's a great and very welcoming community. I lived there my freshman and sophomore years and was pretty involved and now it's a great place to non-res. The facilities are pretty nice, and its location, as an engineer, you can't beat it.  Now I use it as a place to study, especially since Mudd is closed.
nonres_quotes.dorm: College of Cultural and Community Studies

nonres_quotes.name: rogers1
nonres_quotes.text: RoHo is so underrated which is part of its beauty. The rooms are really nice. I have a friend who chose to live there twice which really says something.

nonres_quotes.name: rogers2
nonres_quotes.text: What's RoHo?

nonres_quotes.name: rogers3
nonres_quotes.text: I don’t know much about RoHo but I had a friend who lived there sophomore year and had a great experience. They have really nice rooms.

nonres_quotes.name: allison5
nonres_quotes.text: Even though it's big, it still seems like a random dorm.

nonres_quotes.name: allison6
nonres_quotes.text: It’s one of those places that you know you’re always jealous of people who live there because the rooms are spacious. It doesn’t feel like a classic dorm, it feels like a hotel.

nonres_quotes.name: bobb1
nonres_quotes.text: Bobb is the most social dorm on campus. I don't think it's any nicer than elder but it's much more social. I feel like people who live in Bobb make friends faster if they live there their freshman year.

nonres_quotes.name: bobb2
nonres_quotes.text: Bobb is a jungle. Only those who live in the jungle truly understand it, and everyone outside of it can only admire it.

nonres_quotes.name: bobb3
nonres_quotes.text: “I have heard that Bobb is boisterous, obnoxious, and banging walls in the middle of the night. I don't think I could handle the craziness of Bobb for a year”

featured_articles.title: Gameday
featured_articles.teaser_sentence: Prepare for the experience of your first Northwestern football game and learn about the terrifying, heartbreaking and chaotic aspects of gameday.

featured_articles.title: Changing the Composition
featured_articles.teaser_sentence: Before next winter's Rush, learn more about the changes the Greek system is trying to achieve.

featured_articles.title: Dormroom Ball Pits
featured_articles.teaser_sentence: Bedrooms, ball pits – they're all the same at Northwestern. Some Hinman residents decided their room needed a little more decoration.

featured_articles.title: When should you go to the gym?
featured_articles.teaser_sentence: Want to avoid people when you workout? Check out this interactive to find your favorite Northwestern gym's quietest hours.

featured_articles.title: A Decade of Degrees
featured_articles.teaser_sentence: Going in undecided? Explore how the popularity of majors has changed over time – maybe you'll find the one that's perfect for you.

featured_articles.title: Dorms of Years Past
featured_articles.teaser_sentence: NBN went to the archives to find out more about dorm life. Take a look back at the history of six Northwestern residences.

featured_articles.title: Northwestern Soundscapes
featured_articles.teaser_sentence: It can be easy to forget, but Northwestern's campus has its own distinct sounds. Never forget the Sheridan Road crosswalk and so many others with our project.

featured_articles.title: The Inequality of Busy
featured_articles.teaser_sentence: Biggest college lesson: the amount of free time you have suddenly vanishes. Here's one student's take on the business of Northwestern.

featured_articles.title: Dance Marathon 2016
featured_articles.teaser_sentence: Dance Marathon is one of the biggest events at Northwestern each year. Look at these videos, polls and photos to see what it's like.

featured_articles.title: Evanston Restaurant Guide
